results.title: Further skills
results.creator_credit: Don Kelly and Gerard Holdsworth Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Judo”.
The object of the fourth film is to “sound off” the basic skills of judo. In this demonstration harai-goshi and uchi-mata are contrasted and tsurikomi-goshi - a blocking type of throw, some immobilisations, throws, and ankle-trips are illustrated.

results.title: Judging people
results.creator_credit: Arthur Swerdloff, Leon S. Gold and Roundtable Productions
results.brief_description: Shows frequent pitfalls in sizing up people, as well as methods of avoiding mistakes in making decisions about people, and predicting their performance. Tells how to improve one’s ability to analyze and judge personality, intelligence, ability and capacity.

results.title: Journey into spring
results.creator_credit: Ralph Keene, Edgar H. Anstey, Ian Ferguson and British Transport Films
results.brief_description: Spring comes to Selborne, where the 18th century naturalist Gilbert White made his record of the wild life in his Hampshire parish; rook and dabchick; frog and slow-worm, hedgehog, mole and vole; pussywillow, catkin, celandine, primrose. Two centuries later, as these and other forms of life respond to the seasonal rhythm, the story of spring is patiently recorded by probing camera and microphone and by the evocative words of Laurie Lee.

results.title: Jordan Paul : one teacher's approach (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Vaughn Ohern, Gary Schlosser and Extension Media Centre
results.brief_description: Jordan Paul’s approach to the drug problem is to relate to his students, by any means he can, in order to communicate about drug abuse. His approach is non-directive, he has problems to over come as an authority figure, but he promotes the substitution of people as an alternative to drugs. High school students discuss aspects of drug education.

results.title: Jonas Salk: science of life
results.creator_credit: Peter Poor, Isaac Kleinerman and CBS Network
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “21st Century”.
Dr Jonas Salk, at his Institute for Biological Studies, is seeking ways to fuse the two disciplines of the scientist and humanist. It is vital for scientists and humanists to work together, he claims, ‘to make the decisions and choices that nature has made until now…for the greatest value to human life and society as a whole’.

results.title: John Huston
results.creator_credit: Hugh Burnett and BBC Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Face to Face”.
John Freeman interviews the distinguished American film director John Huston. Originally signed as a writer for Warner Brothers in 1938, his career was interrupted by the war. In 1948 he won the New York Film Critics Award for the Best Direction with “Treasure of Sierra Madre” which simultaneously earned his father Walter Huston an Oscar. His other films include “The Asphalt Jungle” “Moulin Rouge”, “Moby Dick” and “The Misfits”. In this probing interview, John Huston responds to questions related to censorship, the responsibility of the director and his reasons for selecting to work in this medium. He also frankly discusses his childhood, his marriages and his hopes.

results.title: Job evaluation and merit rating
results.creator_credit: Art Babbitt, Edward L. Gershman, Academy Productions and McGraw-Hill Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Personnel Management”.
Situations in an industrial plant are used to show the value of analysing accurately the type of work required in jobs on different levels and of rating objectively the performances of individual employees at their assigned tasks.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Art Babbitt, Edward L. Gershman, Academy Productions and McGraw-Hill Films

results.title: Jewellery through 7000 years (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Pieces from Ancient Egypt, China, Sumeria, Greece, Celtic Europe and Byzantium, and examples of the Gothic Renaissance, Elizabethan and Art Nouveau styles are shown. Old techniques for working gold are demonstrated. Also refers to the superstitious, mythological, cultural and religious influences on jewellery design and usage.
